author: {'steamid': '76561197999282226', 'num_games_owned': 972, 'num_reviews': 201, 'playtime_forever': 2186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2086, 'last_played': 1561664985}
review:
Ys Seven is an Ys title that delivers everything fans of the series have come to expect (fast, frenetic ARPG combat, anime-JRPG stories, and high energy orchestral and rock music) and adds its new twist to the formula for the first of the new trilogy of games: The Party System. I won't spend much time on the graphics or the music except to say that they're absolutely up to the standards of the Ys series, as is the general gameplay and boss fights.

Ys 1 and 2 were the original games, using a basic 'bump combat' system and a very basic magic system. Origins, Felghana, and Napishtim expanded this with more versatile spells, extra weapon types, and skills and Boost modes. Seven (as well as Dana and Celceta) expand this again with the Party System, allowing 3 characters to be controlled at once. Each character also has an array of skills to learn, breaking up the dodge-attack-dodge loop even more.

Combat is what you'd expect from Ys, very stick and move throughout the entire game. Characters have 3 different weapon types through the party: two characters each for Slash, Pierce, and Impact. Adol himself gets weapons for all three damage types, allowing you to mix and match your favorites without needing to worry about doubling up. Adol himself can't be removed from the party. Different enemies are weak to different types of damage, and characters can be swapped on the fly, both midcombat, and, when not in bossfights, even the entire party. This means there's never a break in the action, and enemy weaknesses become a reason to use all your party members and skills in rapidfire succession. The AI is competent, and has boosts to its dodging and defenses, so mostly it will be the character you control taking damage and aggro. Skills can be levelled up by using them more often, and the party also charges an "EXTRA" gauge, which can be spent for a flashy super move. Of note: On higher difficulties, enemy stats scale up, and your normal damage slightly scales down - but the bonus damage you get for attacking enemy weaknesses actually increases in higher difficulty levels, encouraging you to synergize your party even more.

There is one mechanic everyone should be aware of that is never touched on in the game outside the physical manual, and that's the "Flash Guard". When holding down the Skill button, pressing the opposite trigger (on controller) activates "Flash Guard", essentially aparry that completely nullifies all damage, gives skill points to use skills with, and charges EXTRA. There is no cooldown on a successful Flash Guard, and it works on every single attack in the entire game. Final boss spamming a giant laser on you? Just keep mashing Flash Guard, and you'll take 0 damage and come out with an almost totally full SP gauge. Mastery of enemy attack timings and Flash Guard makes you damn near invincible, and if you intend to play Nightmare, it's a critical skill to master, as not only does it do all the above, but a successful Flash Guard gives you guaranteed critical hits for the next few seconds on evrything, including using EXTRA.

Overall, a fantastic addition to the Ys series, and also one that can serve as a first entry into the series, if someone is alright missing some of the references to earlier games, specifically in regards to one party member and their motivations. Easily one of the best in the series, and a recommendation to any A-RPG lover.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042271587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 1044, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1044, 'last_played': 1556734363}
review:
Super action-j-rpg.

Des personnages sympathiques à rencontrer, une histoire assez classique mais intéressante à suivre et un gameplay agréable.
On incarne Adol, mais on  joue une team de 3 personnages, chacun ayant sa manière de combattre et ses affinités contre certains types d'ennemis (bonus/malus de dégâts, distance/contact etc). C'est assez dynamique à jouer, pas trop difficile une fois qu'on a compris un peu le truc et si on observe les patterns des ennemis/boss. Il s'agira donc de bouger dans tous les sens, esquiver, se protéger puis taper (normal/skill/attaque spéciale, ces deux derniers se remplissant en tapant normalement et en se protégeant sur le bon timing), assez simple et sans prise de tête mais on ne ressent pas forcément une lassitude ou une redondance trop forte malgré tout ça.
Pas grand chose à dire d'autres, en tout cas ça a été plaisant à jouer

+ gameplay simple, dynamique et agréable
+ des personnages attachants
+ difficulté plutôt stable (donc pas en dent de scie)

- scénario assez prévisible et des personnages/situations stéréotypés
- une fin un peu déprimante :'( 

Bref, que vous soyez nouveau ou ancien de la série, le jeu reste franchement sympa à parcourir, les néophytes en tout cas n'y seront pas perdu par rapport au background.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084054056', 'num_games_owned': 697, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 2141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2141, 'last_played': 1554280386}
review:
I've finished this game not too long ago and it has the aura of Ark of Napishtim written all over it. You have big bosses and even more of a challenge are the Titanos as superbosses.  And since it's an Ys game, it's the first of the newer installments to feature team battling.  Most don't get the premise as to why Adol needs to fight on a team but the way of combat done here is rather clever for it's not the usual hack n' slash but more on who you use than how you fight.  Its creativity really changes the way the game plays since you're not only playing as Adol, but other characters as well and they wield different weapons thus the concept on the how to fight. In standard Ys fashion, you got your dungeons which have puzzles within itself and for what its worth, it did pose a healthy challenge. 
If you are a fan of this series or even that of Falcom itself, Ys never disappoints as an RPG series..I do plan on getting around to Lacrimosa of Dana, but as I said, if you enjoy the series..you'll enjoy this as well as the remake of the original series and Origin.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036817121', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1551894251}
review:
I really wish I had play tested this within the return time of purchasing it.  There is no option on steam to give an "undecided" review so I will have to settle on negative for now all for one reason; playability.

Perhaps there is difficulty in trying to emulate PSP games for the PC which I can be forgiving of.  The problem I run into specifically is long loading times.  To give you an example, it takes an average of thirty six seconds after I leave the weapons shop for the town to load.  It took closer to fifty seconds to transition between rooms in the same area.  Opening and closing the menu in Blood Omen : Legacy of Kain is shorter than this.  I should also mention that I am using a 4.0 Ghz processor so I have enough power to run this.  I've also tried several different resolutions and graphic options to help, but to no avail.  I could wait this out but life is painfully short enough as it is.  

I'll instead have to watch a no commentary longplay of this game online to better judge it.  $24.99 down the drain.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069339880', 'num_games_owned': 293, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1927, 'last_played': 1620430788}
review:
Ys Seven is an ARPG developed by Nihon Falcom and localized by Xseed Games. Seven is often heralded as the first modern entry of the Ys series as future installments build upon the foundation that was started in this game. The Ys series has always been known for its emphasis on gameplay and features stand alone stories that it make the franchise quite welcoming to newcomers, and Ys Seven is no exception.

Ys Seven throws you into the role of series protagonist and eternal adventurer Adol Christin who wanders from land to land in search of adventure. In this installment Adol will journey through the land of Altago whilst facing powerful foes and gathering allies to aid him in his travels.
As per the standard for Falcom and Ys the gameplay is at the forefront as the story is simple and fast paced. The majority of your time in Altago will be spent travelling the kingdom, fighting enemies, finding rare artifacts, and undertaking quests from the populace, all the while listening to the varied soundtrack that Falcom is known for.
As a PC port of a psp game from 2007, it should function marvelously even on dated systems. There are a variety of resolutions, textures and models have been upscaled, shadow options, and a choice of 30 or 60 fps. This is a great port of a great game and I cannot recommend it enough

author: {'steamid': '76561198036918089', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 3299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2174, 'last_played': 1547524941}
review:
A wonderful addition to the Ys legacy. Taking place after Ys VI Ark of Napishtim if you are playing the games canonically.

At first i was hesistant because of the  party system taking over the elemental weapon system from previous Ys games, But low and behold it works quite well and the combat is vastly different from previous games as a result. Ys 7 brings everything great from previous titles, grinding for levels and money doesn't feel like a chore, synthesizing is the new feature which lets you craft weapons and items from monsters that you've beaten and it helps offset the constant worry about gold.

The music of Ys is always fantastic  and Ys 7 dosn't disappoint here. Probably one of the best desert themes in a video game i've ever heard. Voices can also be turned off in the menu if you don't like them.

The combat features 3 types of damage depending on the enemy you face slashing, blunt, or piercing. You have to swap between 3 characters in order to do massive damage to these types of enemies, the game will let you know as well. There is also a new guard system, so far on my nightmare playthrough i haven't utilized it very much but it's a handy little effect that can block most direct attacks for a few seconds.

In conclusion, Ys 7 has a new engine with new combat, new music, and a new standard for Ys. As all games after Ys 6 will follow the party system(Memories of Celcetta, Ys 7, Ys 8). So this game will give you a feel for how things will work in the following games. But so far the game is fantastic and hopefully you will enjoy it as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037697636', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 367, 'playtime_forever': 1971, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1724, 'last_played': 1544990119}
review:
The parts of games that rub my nose in the most painfully obvious of things needs to stop. Whether it's the story, the gameplay, or literally the path forward 2 inches in front of me, you don't have to rub my nose in it, and it's super condescending when you do so.

The actual review: The gameplay is fine, as it is in all Ys games. However, the writing is just embarassingly bad. The story is utterly cliche and the characters are just collections of terrible tropes. Ys 7 even commits the cardinal sin of doubling up on having to visit each location. The worst part though is probably that 90% of the dialouge could be cut without losing anything between how painfully obvious the story is and how utterly overwritten it is.

On the plus side, there's a fast forward button.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030980822', 'num_games_owned': 253, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2075, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2075, 'last_played': 1513461004}
review:
Strictly fun only in a turn-your-brain-off kind of way. The amount of decline in Seven compared to Oath in Felghana/Origin is astounding.

What you get here is a mashfest which does nothing to change up how its played over the course of it's 20-hour length. Dungeon design has been completely simplified and platforming practically eliminated together with the removal of the ability to jump. Dungeons are nothing more than extremely simple mazes with enemies at every single turn of the road, with the occasional "puzzle" which simply comes down to equipping a key item and then unequipping it once you get past it instead of being a core ability with more depth to its usage. Oh no, it's a pool of lava. What do you do? Equip the ice amulet which let you walk over it safely.  There's no intricacies involved to using it as there would be to a new ability in your usual metroidvania. Consider the opportunities the elemental amulets in Oath/Origin offered for both combat and exploration.

Every enemy type comes down to mindlessly-charges-at-you or shoots-projectile-at-you with barely any variation other than debuffs inflicted and the size and amount of HP. Enemy types are rarely mixed together to create interesting encounters. Most boss fights play out almost exactly the same, and they're ridiculously tanky no matter how much you grind for gear or levels. Just walk up to them, spam your skills, and Flash Guard anything they throw at you. Unfortunately all bosses are ridiculously bulletspongy as most of them don't even have any second phases or intensifying attacks as the fight goes on, making them feel incredibly repetitive.

The Flash Guard maneuver has had the most disastrous effect on the game. Basically, it lets you parry [b]anything[/b]. Giant dragon claws crushing you, tornadoes, [i]even if the whole arena fills with lava you can still Flash Guard it and walk away unscathed.[/i] It protects you from any damage, it makes your SP/EXTRA gauge fill faster, and it also gives you a temporary damage boost, so there's little reason why you wouldn't do it. But because it can parry literally everything, it also makes every attack the same. Giant fireballs? Sweeping claws? Enemies trying to crush you from above? Arena filling with lava? Just Flash Guard it. That's literally all there is to it. The only difficult part is memorizing the timings but after a few tries you should be golden. There's none of the frantic moving around and having to think about your positioning that was present in Oath/Origin. You can literally just stand still in front of the boss' face, mash attack, and Flash Guard when he's about to attack you. Every fight will be like this.

The new party system could be good, it just isn't. For starters, the party AI is completely useless. Party members will try attacking enemies for barely any damage, only to get tons of damage in return. Do you like your party members taking damage even though you have no control over them? Get used to having to switch to a party member with only 1HP left if the one you just played as got knocked out. What's more, every party member doesn't play that radically different from the other. Party members have different basic attack combos and skills, but aside from that they play near-identical in terms of defense and movement. Consider the differences between playable characters in any kind of 2D beat 'em up, and then compare them to the differences between party members in Seven. The only reason you're often switching between them is because some party members deal damage of a certain type which some enemies are weak to while being resistent to others.

Each party member has around 12 skills to extend their basic moveset. The thing is, you can only equip four. Instead of being part of your basic moveset, you'll just end up equipping the skills which deal the highest DPS, rather because of their uitility. Even moreso when you consider that skills take up a finite (but rechargeable) resource. Evenso, alot of skills per characters are near identical in purpose, with some skills being straight-up stronger versions of existing ones but higher SP costs. It's only made worse is that each party member has some minor variation of the same skill archetype which only makes each party member feel more identical. Almost every party member has at least four of these: an uppercut-launcher, a Stinger, a ranged attack, a circular AoE attack, a linear AoE attack, a flurry combo, etc.

The grinding in Seven is somewhat worse since you have to grind for material drops now in order to be able to craft better gear, material drops often dropping based on chance. Each separate skill can be leveled each time you use it, but the leveling requirements can get as ridiculous as having to use a skill over [i]500 times[/i] just to advance a single level. There's items to let you speed up this grind, but it doesn't really take away the core of the issue.

Also, [b]the final boss expects that you have leveled all your party members evenly. You will have screwed yourself over royally if you didn't, even though there's nothing to suggest that was ever expected from you.[/b]

Pros:
[list]
[*]Great music
[*]Combat feels fun and snappy
[*]The places you visit are varied
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*]Flash Guard completely simplifies avoiding damage by letting you block anything
[*]Dumb-ass party AI
[*]Party members don't play that differently from eachother
[*]Dungeon design is incredibly repetitive and overly simplistic outside the occasional platforming gimmick
[*]Forced backtracking halfway through the game
[*]The grinding here is even worse than for usual Ys standards
[*]Having to manually re-(un)equip key items is cumbersome
[*]Nearly all boss fights are tanky bulletsponges with no sense of progression, and almost all of them play out the same due to Flash Guarding
[*]Skill system is poorly realized, individual skill statistics are not explained at all, and basically you will only be using the most damaging skill over and over
[*]Very little variation in how combat plays out over the course of the game
[/list]

[b]5/10[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198022311251', 'num_games_owned': 1210, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 4448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2089, 'last_played': 1586325125}
review:
Ys SEVEN marks a new stage in the series. While previous games focused entirely on a single character, this one puts players in control of a party of three, capable of switching between them on the fly. This feels like a natural progression of the swords from Ark of Napishtim and the magics from Oath in Felghana and Origin.

Taking place after Ys VI -- what a concept -- SEVEN finds our intrepid adventurer Adol "the Red" Christin and his companion Dogi "the Wall Breaker" safely reaching the shores of Altago, an island nation with enough military might to cause the omnipresent Romn Empire to retreat. In fact, Adol and Dogi come to the rescue of two young girls being harassed by members of the Dragon Knights, Altago's most elite soldiers. After this scuffle, they find themselves arrested but are released as their reputation as adventurers precedes them. From there, the town elder tasks the two with discovering the cause of earthquakes that have been rocking Altago to its core. They journey to various other villages within the nation, conferring with the their elders only to discover that the country's ancient deities, the Five Great Dragons are awakening to prevent an oncoming tragedy that may wipe out the entire island -- one that has happened before. But is everything as it seems?

In addition to the party system, SEVEN's gameplay shifts substantially from the last three games. Jumping has been disabled, but characters are given a new dodge roll mechanic, as well as the Flash Guard technique which allows the characters to block attacks and gain extra energy to perform special attacks. Each character has an assortment of special attacks which are unlocked by equipping new weapons and leveling up the attacks themselves to add them to the character's repertoire permanently, as well as an "EXTRA" attack, which is a super powerful technique unique to each character.

SEVEN returns to a traditional world map, sending players throughout Altago, starting at the unoriginally named "Altago City", the nation's major port city, before travelling to the forested Shannoa Village, the deserts surrounding Segram Village and the windy heights of Segram Village. The warping mechanic from previous games returns to make backtracking a breeze. The dungeons have something more of a Zelda flavor to them as well, as many of them contain special items that are used for rudimentary puzzle solving.

A lot of criticism has come out about the game's graphics, mainly focusing on the fact that the game is locked at a maximum resolution of 1080p. This is due to the fact that XSEED was unable to obtain high-resolution textures and was forced to make due with the original art assets from the PSP version (running at a 480x272 resolution) and decided that going any higher would've made for a hideous game. On the plus side, the fine folks at Hyde Inc. did manage to get the game running at a solid 60fps, double what the PSP version was capable of.

As per usual, Falcom's music is amazing. There's also some minor English voice acting in this game. Some people have complained that the original Japanese isn't an option, but honestly, there's so little VA in this game, it shouldn't matter. I just think it's a nice touch that the original Japanese text is present.

I've heard a lot of people suggest SEVEN as one of the better games to introduce new players to the Ys franchise and I can't help but agree. It's not mired in too much of the previous game's continuity -- Ys VI gave a proper to conclusion to the overarching plot of the previous games and there are few connections to it in SEVEN. The game is a bit on the easy side -- I did my first playthrough on Hard Mode and it didn't seem too different from the Normal difficulty in previous titles -- but that kind of works to a newbie's advantage in my book. If you haven't played any prior Ys games, I'd suggest either starting with this one or Oath in Felghana. You can't really go wrong either way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095924054', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 229, 'playtime_forever': 1489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1489, 'last_played': 1534071327}
review:
Great game!

I want to point out Ys origin is what made me buy this game, the other previous version before Origin felt unsatisfying. 

It's hard to point out the pleasent experience of the game, so I'll list what I dislike like about it first and then hopefully provide some decent points in why its good. 

Negatives:

1. I didn't like the randomize item drops from enemies meaning if I were to farm for something it would become very tedious.
2. I didn't enjoy the button holding SP generator mechanic, I spent 80% of the time using that to attack the enemy. I'm fine with the flash guard block beacause that makes sense but the combat experience for me was slightly ruined.
3. Force to spam the roll button to travel at a faster speed.
4.Skill leveling was another unnecessary grinding mechanic
5.Story wasn't that interesting to me but thats more of a personal thing.
6.Having three characters on the battlefield can be very distracting, making it harder to fight or just miss out on the awesome visual aspects.

positives:

1.Nice fluid combat with many different skills to utilize for your characters, which makes it harder to lose interest.
2. I luv the idea of obtaining the Optional ultimate weapons for your characters
3. Instant travel, once unlock can make your journey or progression alot more convenient
4. Two optional bosses
5. A navigation point on your map to help locate your next objective
6.journal to identify which monster drops what item
7.Many different character to utilize with unique skill sets and special
8.Boss fight was fun but can sometimes be ridiculously hard or tedious if underleveled.
9. I enjoyed the layout of the levels

As a side note for some of the negative portion of the game. I'm aware you can purchase, locate or aquire rewards to make some of the points less of a burden but it was far too late to notice it and it still required a little bit of grinding to it.

Still this was a fun game and i recommend looking at a guide to help with enhancing your experience which I wish I've done sooner.

author: {'steamid': '76561198414164728', 'num_games_owned': 406, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 27579, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26201, 'last_played': 1593392522}
review:
日本国内では2009年にPSPで発売されたイース7のPC移植版（中国では先に発売済み）。
PCに移植ということもあり、くっきりとした画質や解像度の設定、PSP版で不満点だったエキストラスキルの発動ボタンの独立など、様々な変更点がみられます。
ゲーム内の文章はそのまま日本版からすべて持ってきているため、不自由なくプレイ可能です。
逆に英語にしたりしてみて、いろいろとやるもの楽しいかもしれません。

基本的にゲーム内容自体はPSP版とほとんど変わらず、追加要素が存在しません。
評価点はPSP版据え置きですが、ロードが早い点などは評価するべきでしょう。
ただ、問題点として挙げられるのは、日本語ボイスがないことですかね…。これは少し仕方ないかも。

author: {'steamid': '76561198013658567', 'num_games_owned': 3716, 'num_reviews': 420, 'playtime_forever': 94498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 607, 'last_played': 1653106586}
review:
Hab mir Ys Seven gekauft weil ich bereits von "Trails in the Sky" super begeistert war. Falcom und Xseed sind in meinen Augen eine der besten Rollenspielhersteller die es gibt und gerade Square-Enix könnte sich ein gewaltige Scheibe abschneiden.

Ys Seven erzählt die Geschichte von Adol und Dogi. Beide sind Abenteurer sie auf einem Kontinent landen auf welchem dann diverse Abenteuer bestanden werden müssen. Die Spielzeit dürfte bei ca. 30-50 Stunden liegen. Das Kampfsystem ist sehr dynamisch und findet komplett in Echtzeit statt. Spezialattacken können erlernt werden und es gibt zig Waffen und Rüstungen. Gegner verlieren nach ihrem Ableben Geld und Rohstoffe die man zur Synthese neuer Waffen und Rüstungen verwenden kann. Bossgegner sind meist rießig und fordern durchaus Strategie vom Spieler.

review: As a long time lover of the Ys series I can't say i am impressed. I have been playing since Ark of Napishtim on the PSP and have gone back and played all of the previous games too. Although the storyline is fascinating and amazing as usual, I really could not stand the graphics, the movements are slow, blocky and generally don't flow. The lines of text are slow, and unable to be skipped, making this game slow and unsuited to it's fast paced storyline. Even when controlling the character, it is slow and the movements are very, very dragged out. The only redeeming factor of this game is the amazing cutscenes. Like the previous games, the hand-drawn cutscenes (which rarely appear) are a sight to behold. But even so, getting to these cutscenes take a long time. Overall, i do not suggest buying this game, slow gameplay and half-hearted graphics make it so that your money is basically wasted, unless you have a lot of time to burn.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993312863', 'num_games_owned': 16891, 'num_reviews': 535, 'playtime_forever': 3240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3240, 'last_played': 1529379231}
review:
This is my favorite Ys game so far (haven't played MoC or VIII yet) and a fantastic game in general. All the typical pillars of a Ys game are present (action, music, fast paced play and funny moments) as well as new aspects like a more engrossing story and a bigger cast of enjoyable characters. As with any Ys game, the boss fights are a treat and rarely feel unfair when utilizing patience, flash guarding, dodging, the occassional health item and more patience!

There are a vast array of enemies to fight, items to collect and abilities to play around with. There is some backtracking (some forced, some not), but as far as I'm concerned, it nets needed resources anyway. The A.I. is generally pretty competent, except for the times (usually boss fights) where they just don't attack if Adol isn't engaged with the enemy as well. The game plays like butter at 60 FPS and generally looks servicable for its age (except for some textures such as the harbor, *shudder*). Dialog in the various towns also updates as you progress through the story, so feel free to waste an hour or two (or more!) just chatting up the townsfolk.

Overall, this is a very well done game. With 4 different difficulties, just about anyone can come in and be challenged at an appropriate level. I easily recommend this to any fans of Ys or anyone that enjoys fast paced action RPGs.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998010777', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2748, 'last_played': 1526949848}
review:
Fantastic game. Don't let the early-2000s dated graphics deter you from playing this immensly rich, action-oriented game. Like Ys VIII and Ys Memories of Calceta, you play not only as Adol but also can control two others in your party, and switch them out almost at any time. The story is fantastic, and has more than a few twists I didn't see coming, which was very refreshing.  The combat never gets old. There's just something satisfying about leveling up your characters and their gear, then going back to a once hard enemy and wiping them out in one hit.

There are a few dozen side quests you can unlock, which give some decent rewards. However, it is possible to fail a quest because you went too far into the story. I failed like 6 of them. Oh well.

I played it on Hard Mode, and it kicked my ass, but after 45 hours of playtime, I beat it. A few times a fight came down to me with no recovery potions left and like 50 hit points. But whatevs, I won.

I also recommend every other Ys game on Steam, except for VIII. That still needs work on the PC version. PS4 version is amazing, tho'.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100910014', 'num_games_owned': 1612, 'num_reviews': 366, 'playtime_forever': 1506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1506, 'last_played': 1524244847}
review:
Es una saga que me hubiera gustado conocerla antes
para haberla disfrutado mas intensamente de todas
formas no me arrepiento en abosoluto.

La conocí mediante un Steam por supuesto con Oath
in Felghana que me pareció un videojuego solido en
todos los apartados.

A nivel narrativo es bastante profundo ya que los
personajes principales se expresan de un modo
muy sentimental en todo momento.

En el aspecto jugable me parece muy acertado
como esta planteado desde una perspectiva
casi isométrica,con gran diseño de mazmorras
con jefe final esperando al acabar el recorrido
a veces incluso dos.

En concreto este utiliza un sistema de party's
bien pensado,pudiendo cambiar entre los
miembros del grupo en cualquier momento,
en función de la situación que se nos presenta.

Existen tres tipos de ataque:

-Corte
-Penetrante
-Pesado

El personaje principal aparece en todas y cada
una de sus entregas,un sello diferenciador que
le otorga personalidad,ya que el personaje no
tiene dialogo,solamente es capaz de tomar
decisiones en cada momento.

La trama del juego es una maravilla aunque
quiza no diste mucho de algo génerica que
toman otros del mismo género.

Lo recomiendo bastante como juego de acción
que combina el rol de forma muy light,la única
pega es que no esta traducido,pero a estas
alturas deberiamos dominar más o menos
el inglés.

No tiene un nivel muy alto de manera que
podremos comprenderlo casi al completo.

En definitiva es un juego que como amante
de los rpg's de corte nipón deberiamos
probar....

Es la misma versión que PSP,sólo que han
sido añadidos ajustes gráficos y la opción
de jugarlo a 60 frames por segundo que
se agradece.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043214842', 'num_games_owned': 144, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 3685, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3323, 'last_played': 1520556973}
review: Ys Seven is a great game.  It's quite a bit different from the earlier 3d Ys games, but I wouldn't say this doesn't makes it better or worse, just different.  Unlike the earlier games, Seven tries to add a bit more to the RPG side of the series.  The story is a bit larger and feels quite a bit more serious than in previous games.  There's now party members, various skills for each party member that level up along with them, special EX attacks, more equipment options, loads of accessories with various effects, and a crafting system.  The combat system is also completely different.  Aside from aforementioned skills and EX attacks, certain enemies have certain weaknesses, and attacking them with the wrong type of weapon will make you either deal significantly less damage, or even no damage at all.  Jumping is also gone, putting the fights in mostly 2d setting.  To compensate for the inability to evade through jumping, the game also introduces a roll ability to let you move around faster, and a guard ability to completely block attacks if timed correctly.  Guarding early punishes you by making you take a guaranteed critical hit, while guarding successfully charges your EX attack gauge slightly and gives you a short period of time with 100% critical hit rate.  Despite all these changes though, this doesn't mean the game is easy by any means.  It's certainly got the same challenge as any other game in the series.  Overall it's a great game and I had a blast with it.  The crafting and skill leveling felt like down points for me though.  Farming materials for new weapons and armor can be a bit of a pain, and similarly, spamming a skill a bunch of times to level it up can be a bit of a hassle.  I found these two points sort of distracted me from the rest of the game a bit.  Beyond that though, I can't really say anything bad about this game, it's definitely really great, and the differences from other Ys games sort of give it a fresh new feel.  I highly recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047819928', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 4562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2439, 'last_played': 1613794811}
review:
I have been playing Ys games since the Turbografx-16, and recently went on a binge catching up on all the recent (relatively speaking) installments. The thing that makes Y's so addictive in my opinion is the combat. The styles have varied over time, but they are always satisfying. The system has been updated a bit here, for the better in my opinion. It's still just as responsive as ever (major strong point of series), and rivals FPS games in the sheer satisfaction of mowing down enemies.

If the game upsets you for any reason (Say, fell off a ledge requiring some back tracking), then god help the nearest enemy, because they WILL suffer the wrath of your irritation and after a few satisfying slashes, special skill blasts, followed by a soul-soothing "RAAAWWRRGGHGHGH" death cry as the HP hits 0......all will be forgiven as you head back up to continue your quest, mowing down more monsters. Need to grind for a bit? (not really required on normal) No problem, it's a good time!

The party system is well done and surprisingly does not slow the game down like i thought it might. They have managed to keep things simple enough to retain the core values of the series while expanding the gameplay. 

This installment gives the best feeling of exploration and adventure so far, as the next towns are often a serious trek through various lands that will have you excited to finally get there and check out the next town.

Story is good in this one. It's not going to win any oscars but I found it to be one of the more captivating of the series, with some serious twists and characters that we get know decently. The coliseum was fantastic - i'll leave it at that to avoid any spoilers.

Synthesis - I was worried this would just feel like work, but fortunately it's never holding you back in normal difficulty and more like a bonus area. I used it here and there, and at the end of the game have decided to pursue a few items before i meet my maker, but most of the things you need to create things are just a dungeon crawl away in the place you were headed anyway.

i've heard complaints of backtracking - not really. Yes you revisit some places in the second half, but only to get to brand new areas. This game has no more backtracking than any other self respecting RPG. It's an adventure, and you should get to know the world. RPG's should not be linear, but either way there is really not anything that feels cheap or recycled here, again since you end up in brand new areas as a result of said backtracking, once again marvelling in a new area to conquer.

Graphics are 2nd rate by 2017 standards but still look good and serve the game well. 

Bosses, while looking good for the era and still as menacing as ever, lack some of the absolutely required strategy of older Y's games. It's a bit easier to button mash away in this installment, probably the biggest set back vs previous Ys games. Still, the bosses are fun battles and if you value your potions you'll need to pay mind to the patterns and do lots of dodging. They are the longest boss battels in the series yet, and if you take the impatient button mashing/potion popper route your thumbs will be begging for mercy half way through the battle - incentive enough to tighten up and start minding the patterns and such....

Music is excellent as always with Y's games - the boss music always gets me pumped. There are some treats for players of previous games in music dept. The early Y's games have the most memorable music in video gaming - there is nothing on that level here, but for any other series i'd call it excellent.

Speaking as a fan of the series,  I give this a 9/10. it's affecting my sleep schedule.

review:
Not sure how I feel about having harvest points and skill grinding and item crafting in my Ys; to be honest it feels like it stacks too much on top of a good, basic formula. On the other hand, it's still much the same action-y goodness of previous titles. Heck, having a whole traveling party makes fighting even wilder, with specials all popping off at once and you dodge-rolling out of danger while your allies whoop on the enemy.

If you're a fan of the series, get it. If you're not, get it anyway, because I'm a stranger on the internet, and if you can't trust MY opinions, whose can you trust?

author: {'steamid': '76561198070273511', 'num_games_owned': 1114, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 3901, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3831, 'last_played': 1578742305}
review:
Ys Seven; oyunun sonundayım ultimate silahları yaptım, ultimate zırhların bir kısmı kaldı onları da aldıktan sonra geriye gidip son kalan bossları kesmek kalıyor. Oyunu en zorda (nightmare) oynuyorum. 

Oynanış olarak hızlı ve keyifli oynanışı var. Sıra tabanlı diye JRPG den uzak duranlara önerebileceğim en iyi oyunlardan biri. Hatta seri diyebilirim. Oynanış olarak YS serisi çok keyiflidir. Bi dark souls, bi zelda kadar güzel oynanışı var. Bildiğin yağ gibi akıyor. Sevenda 7 farklı karakter var kontrol edebildiğimiz ve bunların üçünü aynı anda kullanabiliyoruz. Geri kalan dördünü istediğimiz an menüden seçebiliyoruz. Karakterler arası geçişte çok kolay tek tuşla istediğimiz an bir karakterden diğerine geçebiliyoruz. 

Oyunda her karakterin kendini özgü ultimate skili var. Başlarda bunların düşük seviye olanları açıkken, ilerde bazıları hikaye ile bazıları ise yan görevlerle açılıyor. 20 tane yan görev var oyunda bunlardan 12 tanesi oyunda belli bir aşamaya gelince (daha doğrusu bir mekana gidince) iptal oluyor. O aşamaya kadar da size bol bol vakit veriyor oyun görevi yapmanız için. Hepsini yapmanıza gerek yok ama spo vermeden ucundan söyleyim; iksir görevini, ufak bi yaratık bulma görevi var onu ve 3 tane yaratık kesme görevi var. Bunları yaparsanız çok faydasını görürsünüz. Çokta vakit yemiyorlar zaten. 

Oyunda sentez mekaniği var. Yani çeşitli materialler toplayıp bunları birleştirerek silahlar, zırhlar, aksesuarlar yapabiliyoruz. Bu materiallerin bazıları çevreden bulunurken, bazıları yaratıklardan düşüyor. Hangi yaratık hangi materiali düşürüyor monster listden bakabilirsiniz. Ben harvest edilebilenleri etraftan toplamayı tercih ettim. Daha çabuk toplanıyor o şekilde. Ayrıca bir yerdeki materiali topladıktan kıa bir süre sonra o material tekrardan orda ortaya çıkıyor. Başka türlü de olmazdı zaten. Ultimate silah ve zırhları yapmak için (tüm karakterlere) sırf 450 den fazla soul stone gerekiyor. 100 tane başka itemden 250 tane bir başkasından. Gözünüz korkmasın çok hızlı bir şekilde topluyorsunuz bunları. 3-3 buçuk saat civarı bir sürede tüm karakterlerin ultimate setini yapabilirsiniz. 

Oyunda skiller silahlara özel ama burda şöyle bir güzellik var. Skili öğrendiğiniz an o silahı gidip satabilirsiniz. Ve o öğrendiğiniz skili başka silahlarda da kullanabiliyorsunuz. Bir güzellikte şu skilki öğrenmek için dövüşe girmeniz gerekmiyor. Takın skill boost veren aksesuarı sonra öğrenmek istediğiniz skili boşa yapsanızda yaptın sayıyor oyun. Sonraki seviyeye kaç exp kaldığını menü equipten skilin üzerine gelerek öğrenebilirsiniz. Skilleri kullanabilmek için mana gerekiyor. Oyunda maximum mana 100. Mana ise çeşitli şekillerde dolduruluyor. Bunlar; iksir içme ki nightmare de o iksirden sadece 1 tane taşıyabiliyorsunuz. Dövüşler esnasında vuruşunuza-iteminize bağlı olarak; bunu açacam ya da bulduğunuz bir item sayesinde etrafta dolaşırken kendiliğinden doluyor. Dövüşte vuruşa bağlı olarak mana dolması şu; saldırı tuşuna bir basılı tutup sonra bırakırsanız 15-20 civarı manayı birden dolduruyor. Öteki türlü 3-5 3-5 gıdım gıdım doluyor yani. İteminize bağlı derken de; dövüşlerde mana dolumunu hızlandıran bir aksesuar var. 100 bin gold civarı bir paraya satın alabilirsiniz bu. 

YS Sevenın bir güzelliği de şu; bir çok oyunda itemi alırsınız 100 liraya satarsınız 30 liraya. 70 lira girer. Hadi bu önemsiz bir miktar. 5 bin bayılırsınız iteme lan bu işime yaramıyormuş dersiniz geri satarsınız 200 lira vermez şerefsiz satıcı. Bu oyunda o yok. 25bin mi verdiniz iteme 25 bine satarsınız. Ayrıca bir itemin fiyatı A dükkanında neyse B dükkanında da odur. Dükkanlardan bahsetmişken 3-4 milyon rahat harcamışımdır, senteziydi, silah-zırh almasıydı, potuydu falan derken. Zaten bir tane item var fiyatı 1 milyon. Oynarsanız görürsünüz.

Hikayeye gelince Ark of Napisthimin bittiği yerden başlıyor. Ve grubuzdaki bir karakter Ark of Napisthimde hikayede çok önemli bir yere sahip. Doğrudan bu oyundan başlamak yerine YS 1-2 chroniclesden başlayıp sırayla gitmek daha doğru olur. Doğrudan sevenı oynarsınız diğerlerini oynamadan ama hikayeye önem veriyorsanız YS 1-2 chroniclesden başlayıp; origin-celceta-felghana ... diye hikaye sırasıyla giderseniz daha güzel olur. Seven hikayenin sonu. Direkt sevendan başlamak - durumu tam  olarak açıklamasa da şöyle örnek vereyim - game of thrones a 6. sezondan başlamak gibi bir şey olur. 

Oyun orjinalinde psp oyunu ve 8-10 yıllık bir oyun. PC ye yeni çıktı (2017 de) o yüzden pek bir grafik beklemeyin. Grafik fetişistlerine göre değil bu oyun. 

Şu ana kadar ki kısım için puan verecek olursam 86/100 rahatlıkla verebileceğim bir puan. Kaba tabirle oyunun rahat bir 80 ederi var ki bu da YS Sevenın gayet iyi bir oyun olduğunu gösterir. Türü seviyorsanız 40 liraya fazla fazla değen bir oyun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025434087', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 1397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1397, 'last_played': 1517631253}
review:
Overall, Ys Seven is an engaging and enjoyable ARPG which brings hero Adol Christin back for another round with the forces of destruction.

So what doesn't Ys Seven do very well?  Let's get it out of the way first:  The main storyline is a lazy cliche.  First, go collect five things related to the five elements Fire, Water, Air, Earth, and Moon.  Got them?  Ok.  Now collect five different things related to those elements, and go confront the final boss to prevent the destruction of the land.  That's the main storyline in a nutshell, and it really pains me how little effort was put into it.  There is also very little exploration to be done in the game world, and what little there is amounts to making sure you find all the (fairly obvious) treasure nooks in each area.

That's not to say that the whole thing is boring to sit through.  The interactions between characters are more interesting, for example.  I grew fairly fond of the majority of the main cast and was generally interested in their thoughts and feelings about the things happening around them.  Of course what every Ys game really emphasizes, and where this one shines, is combat!

Combat in Ys Seven varies by opponent, and for the most part each area has enemies that will ensure you are exercising your dodging skills.  Most normal mobs are not terribly difficult once you learn their attack patterns, but most will require you to fight intelligently rather than button mash.  Bosses range from fairly easy to very challenging.  When I say this, I mean that their many unique attack patterns can make avoiding damage quite difficult.  Not a problem on the "Normal" difficulty setting, where healing items will let you power through mistakes, but even hardcore gamers will find a challenge on higher settings.  If you are looking for a fun and engaging action RPG, Ys Seven is definitely the game for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198064002064', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 3496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3496, 'last_played': 1514571449}
review:
This is my first Ys game and I have to say that it was a really enjoyable experience. I was first introduced to Falcom games through their incredible Legend of Heroes games and I have always been curious of the Ys franchise for the past couple of years. I figured it was time to stop pondering and take the plunge into Ys Seven, their first 3d Ys title.

All in all, this game screams Falcom storytelling and action, which is a fantastic thing to behold. It took some time to get used to how the game works since I have been so used to the turn based combat of the Trails series, but once I got the hang of it, it became really fun to play.

Pros:

Excellent, fast paced combat.
Good story that draws you in over time.
Fun characters with interesting and funny dialogue.
Plenty of combat Skills that offer variaty of ways to fight.
Good soundtrack, but not even close to the quality of the Kiseki series of soundtracks.

Cons:

A lot of grinding to get everything.
Some environments were annoying to traverse, until you get the item that stops the issue.

In general, this game does many things right and I am eagerly waiting for Ys 8: Lacrimosa of Dana to make its debut onto PC soon, despite XSEED Games not being the ones helming the game. After playing Ys 7, I may consider going back to play the past Ys titles. I definitely recommend Ys 7 to be experienced by those who are: fans of the Falcom games, enjoy fast paced combat, or enjoy a good story, despite the grinding that is most definitely going to occur from the start.

Hope you all enjoy this game as much as I have!

author: {'steamid': '76561198088076351', 'num_games_owned': 1939, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 1807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1807, 'last_played': 1513383412}
review:
Schönes Spiel. Bis zu diesem Zeitpunkt auf jeden Fall storytechnisch imo der stärkste Teil.

Das einzige was mich hier störte war, wie in Final Fantasy 7 bis 9 die Low Res Hintergründe und Texturen. Die Charaktere und Gegner an sich sind grafisch relativ scharf, aber bei manchen Hintergründen, Skyboxen und Texturen hat man nur Pixelmatsch. Das geht so weit das man teilweise nicht ausmachen kann, was das vor einem grad sein soll. Sehr schade das darauf keinen Wert gelegt wurde.

Aber alles in allem kann man dennoch nichts mit einem Kauf falsch machen. Das Ys Kampfsystem sticht weiterhin unter den ARPGs hervor. Macht bis zum Ende Laune. Kaufempfehlung.

Hoffen wir das Memories of Celceta eines Tages noch bei Steam erscheint. <3

author: {'steamid': '76561198203412952', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 1755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1751, 'last_played': 1540826717}
review:
Where to begin where to begin....

Gameplay:
Its your usual Ys action only updated in pretty much every aspect. The controls are tight , the boss fights are amazing (seriously falcom knows how to make boss fights ) , the characters and customizing them is great.
Its really easy to learn and get into AND if you know what you are doing you can with the abilities and accessories that you can get , do some really amazing combos and or just break the game in half (in a good way).

The music:
Its falcom.

The story:
Just like the other Ys games this one follows a simple formula that somehow never gets old for me. I think its mainly because the characters are so lovable in these games. Now its no trails in the sky (another falcom product) but considering Ys is more about fast gameplay that is to be expected. In the end it still managed to get a tear out of me along with other emotions.

The extra optional stuff:
Now this part is a bit tricky. You see in terms of in main game stuff , we have A LOT of stuff to do here. Optional weapons , bosses , abilities etc etc.
BUT it doesnt have the cool boss rush mode , arena modes and the upgraded versions of characters that you can unlock (then again this game has like 7 characters already soooo that is not really an issue).


The negatives:

Now before we begin these are the problems that I have encountered and it is not to say that you will too.

1: Text box glitch. It happened a lot in my run , the text boxes would flicker and while doing that you can continue (unless you press confirm at the right frame since it flickers). I actually had to reset because of this once and redo a boss fight (luckly the boss was really fun)

2: The attack and dash sometimes dont work. Now dont get me wrong everything else works in the menus and stuff AND you can still do charge attacks but I had many times where I would have to wait for my game to let me use my commands.

With all that said and done , I can safely say that Ys 7 is a great game. I don't think its my favorite one cause I still like Origin a bit more. This game improves on a lot and adds in a lot BUT something about that game is just so majestic to me. Its not quite trails in the sky feeling but really similar.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019461224', 'num_games_owned': 1018, 'num_reviews': 154, 'playtime_forever': 2898, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1635, 'last_played': 1534927092}
review:
Ys Seven is an alright game but may disappoint those who are coming from Ys games of Oath and Origin. 
That's the long and short of it.
Ys Seven uses a party system that can sometimes be frustrating and contradicting in a game that throws you into heavy boss fights and enemy encounters with an expectation on using your and your characters skill and ability to beat them.
The party AI is dumb and often uses what your doing as a basis to decide how to foolishly attempt the same thing but worse. 
The game compensates for their inability to properly function by throwing them near you when they get lost or ignoring damage when not in your focus. 
It still seems somewhat offputting that a game with such a focus on a party fails to accurately show the positives and negatives of a party by just using them as a story element or whenever the hell it's convenient to negate their need to use good artificial intelligence. 
Maybe they could have traits that would require resources or certain requirements. 
For better or worse though Sevens party mechanics are fairly barebones, likely to please the people who don't want them but also never fully satisfying the people who do want them.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986543956', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 1733, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1733, 'last_played': 1510363772}
review:
For the very first time I am playing all Ys games. Until very recently I have never played nor seen anyone play any of the Ys games. Around Sept/20 2017 I started with Ys I, then Ys II, followed by Ys VI: The Ark of Napishtim, Ys: The Oath in Felghana, Ys Orgin, Ys Seven, Ys VIII: Lacrimosa of Dana, Ys: Memories of Celceta. Now in in the year 2021 I beat the new game Ys IX: Monstrum Nox. Leaving no current Ys games left on Steam. I will continue this mission of mine if/when more Ys games get ported to Steam. My goal has been reached! Below is how I rank the games I have played and beat so far from best to worst. I love all the Ys games even Ys I. So I am a huge fan of this series. I will edit this review as I play and beat more Ys games.

<Best>
Ys VIII: Lacrimosa of Dana
Ys Seven
Ys IX: Monstrum Nox
Ys: Memories of Celceta
Ys: The Oath in Felghana
Ys: Origin
Ys II 
Ys VI: The Ark of Napishtim 
Ys I
<Worst>

Still Left to Play...
None (As of this moment.)

What I thought of "YS Seven"
I can't fully compare this to all other Ys Games. It's by far the most different Ys game compaired to all the rest even 1 & 2. That said before playing this game I loved the Ys Series but I did not consider it to be one of the greats! Like The Tales of series or Final Fantasy etc. Ys Seven changes that. Is it at least in my opinion the best overall Ys Game. Sure other Ys games are better in some aspects but this is the first Ys game that feels massive. And yes playing the previous Ys game only adds to the greatness of Ys Seven.  

Let me exsplain. This is the first Ys game to have a whole party of charachters and you can have three in your active party at once. The A.I allys are good enough to not get in the way. And this game refuses to end. I was maybe 50%-60% into the game and I thought I was at the very end. It took almost seven hours after that point just to reach the final duneon. So while most Ys games will go for about 5-15 hours game play. Ys Seven is more like 25+ hours and I have yet to finish all side goals to 100% so I may play a little longer. 
 
The combat and attack controls are pretty good no complaints here. Since the game is longer and has many areas the enemies feel a little re-used but only compaired to other Ys Games. But still they get the job done and feel original enough that it's fine.  The boss fights are intense and even though you can use a lot of healing items even during boss battles which is uncommon in Ys it's very difficult. Your going to need to grind exp and loot to win.  Level design is very good. Actually level design is close to the best I have seen Ys offer. No major issues I have with the game. This is my favorite Ys game but the story and chrarachters are way better than other Ys games. I still feel the combat itself is still better represented in Ys Orgin but overall Ys Seven rocks! 

-Update- Since Ys VIII has released it has replaced Ys Seven as my favorite Ys games. But everything I said here still holds true.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995129622', 'num_games_owned': 3102, 'num_reviews': 203, 'playtime_forever': 1272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1272, 'last_played': 1509662990}
review:
Positives
+ Better & longer story than typical Ys games
+ Fluent controls
+ Good localization
+ Superb OST
+ Very fun party system
+ Lots of exploration & adventuring opportunities
+ Never feeled like a grind
+ Great atmospheric levels

Meh
~ N64-styled graphics, a jump from the original pixels. Easy to get used to though
~ If you choose the archer girl to play with, expect a lot of "YAAAAH YAAAAH YAAAAH YAAAAH" on repeat every time you press that normal attack button

Negatives
- None. The mehs were a minor inconvenience which I quickly got used to

This is not the type of story I am used to with Ys games. The jump to 3D was a bit off-setting at first (The game was originally released in 2009, and N64-graphics is not really something I expect in a release of that year. Plus, quite a difference with the original sprite characters) but that's perhaps the only "meh" I could find.

This game is great. I played through the story and everything seemed like a typical Ys game, until somewhere midway when things quickly took a Final Fantasy-styled turn of events. The shift to 3D wasn't as unsettling as I thought when I started, it quickly became as fluent as I'm used to with other Ys games. Music from Ys Seven is superb. Party system is new but also pretty fun - finally able to play as Dogi. Also a very atmospheric feel & design in levels.

It's just slightly below Ys:Origin for me.

9/10. If you like the Ys series, play this game. If you don't like Ys because it's normally too bare-boned, play this game. If you like great RPGs and don't mind the graphics, play this game. If you like silent protagonists, play this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996570836', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 3239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3239, 'last_played': 1509054672}
review:
Good hack and slash game. Closer to the older ys games than the newer ones (which I like). 

 The only 'bad' thing I'd say are some silly pitfalls the game sets you up for:

1. If you want 100% beastiery, you *MUST* do the tutorial at the start of the game ( entries 1 and 2) and *MUST* kill the adds in boss fights. I skipped the tutorial and missed the adds in the water dragon fight, making 100% impossible.
2. The last battle you *MUST* use all characters. So if you were like me, and just focused on 3-4 characters the entire game, the first stage of the fight is 10x harder than the next two combined.

author: {'steamid': '76561198356141989', 'num_games_owned': 2521, 'num_reviews': 637, 'playtime_forever': 4287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1510349770}
review:
Reviewing Ys? Should be automatic at this point! :)
Ys is one of those series which really never fail at every title (Ys I and II to me are awesome games too).
Ys 7 translates all to a 3D plain, and I can't help but think often at Final Fantasy VII for many things. Graphics are great, and as always the soundtrack is really amazing.
For what concerns the gameplay - fully supported XBOX controller, no cheap USB controller though, the one I used with Ys Origins and the other older games - everything runs so smoothly and fast that I can only love it. An action RPG is not a turn-based/strategy game and to me it needs to be fast, transitions need to be fast, and here really I have never experienced a single problem.
You're provided with lots of options, equipment, magic, skills, everything. And it's all scaled so that you start at level 1 and get accustomed to the world, to the new kinds of skills etc. with playing time; there's nothing out of place. You have also the standard Ys difficulty options from easy onwards (four levels unlocked from the start), just in case you're a beginner - however, being this a 3D game advanced in the series, I'd suggest to start with some previous titles available here on Steam too.
All the characters have their own weapons and strength towards enemies, and you can switch between them with just one key; boss fights are more challenging than ever (ok, Ys Origin at times was very difficult XD) and here the game shines even more than during the usual fights that are scatteret through the maps.
Since I'm not a console player I really don't want to say nothing about PSP ports and such; I just talk about this game on Steam, and it runs perfectly! And apart from this everyone says it's even better here than in its original vest, so.. ahah :)
The screen fits all - a perfect minimap, HP, SP, EXP and everything on lower right, enemy stats on the left and so on; really, I rarely saw a game so perfect in every detail and I think that a PC and not a portable console is the best way to enjoy Ys 7. It also features all my favourite things, like, a button to optimize equipment, shortcuts, skipping dialogues.. everything! :)
The plot isn't that thorough, but still definitely enjoyable with also hints to previous titles. You have also lots of sidequest and such; just the achievements to me aren't that greatly placed 'cos they're almost all like "get all the skills", "get everyone to the maximum level".. I think that in RPGs achievements must follow the player from his first steps to the last boss, but anyways, this doesn't affect gameplay.
It's definitely a must to have even if the Ys series isn't super known at least here in Europe; there aren't so many action RPGs better than these and the Seven release really stands up at its best.

review:
Ys SEVEN [PC日本語版] がついにプレイできるようになりました。
[PSP日本語版]では画面が小さかったり、Joyolandの [PC中国語版] しかありませんでした。
おそらくNISAやXSEEDがプレイできるようにしてくれたんですね。ありがとう。
ちなみにJoyolandの豪華版に付いてきたゲームパッドは使用可能でした。

最近のキャラクターデザインに比べるとディテールが少ないの残念ですが、
バトルシステムはアクション性が高くおもしろいです。ボス戦もエキサイティングでおもしろい。
BGMもアドルの冒険シーンをドラマチックに演出してます。

シナリオも、五大竜がアドルになにをさせたいのか、
ティアとマヤがどうなっていくのか、気になるところ。

日本語版でやっとクリアできそうです。最後まで見届けようと思います。

10/21追記
クリアしました。意外な展開で驚きました。
ちょっと残念なような、切ないエンディングでした。
アルタゴには綺麗な花がいっぱい咲くでしょうね。マヤとティアは花摘みを...きっと。
素敵な物語だったと思います。音楽も素晴らしかった。

author: {'steamid': '76561197970398622', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 1447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1447, 'last_played': 1507513633}
review:
Though I’m a long time series fan of Ys, I’ve never played the more recent games designed for PSP and Vita. I just don’t play games portably. So it’s with fresh eyes I played this PC port of Ys Seven. It’s probably the worst Ys game Falcom has made in the 2000s. By regular RPG standards, this is above average. But it doesn’t live up to the standards I’ve come to expect from Ys. And it certainly isn’t a worthy follow-up to Ys Origin.

What makes the Ys series unique is its energetic music, and how it uses deceptively simple mechanics to maximum effect. I don't know of anything that quite captures the same sense of speed and control the way Ys does. Because of the camera perspective, the series has been able to throw an almost bullet hell level of chaos on screen without it feeling unfair. Third person games like Bayonetta or Metal Gear Rising might have a sense of speed and spectacle, but their camera puts limits on how chaotic they can be before you lose control of what's happening. Ys never had that problem. 

The traditional weakness of Ys has been the story, as it’s often bare bones and archetypal. But the series has been around since the 1980s, so it’s been largely on par with the genre as a whole over time. With Ys Origin, the developers aimed higher than usual, and delivered a truly great story for the first time. Unfortunately, in Ys Seven, they stumbled backward into the more archetypal, bland, and unexciting type of stories they were doing before. But in this case with the unpleasant addition of too much text. There are loads of characters in this story, and there's no point to half of them. Ys Origin was nothing like this. It had a vivid cast, with clear motivations, and a focus on what mattered. It made me care. For the majority of Ys Seven, I was bored by the story. Now and then it provided a blip of excitement, but it wasn't enough to make up for the bad parts.

As for how it plays, this feels like an Ys game operating at 75% intensity. For the first time in the series you control a whole party of characters, and this results in visual chaos. You don't get the same level of precision from this new combat system. And I guess to compensate for this new system being more chaotic, you're given more healing items than ever before. As the first game using this system, it isn't bad, but the unique qualities that made Ys good have been diluted and makes the game more ordinary. It has its moments, like the boss fights. Now and then everything clicked, and I got a huge smile on my face. It just didn't happen as regularly as I expect from Ys. For the most part combat in this feels more laid back, not as demanding of the player. It's too bad because it feels like it lost some of the purpose for why you'd even play a Ys game to begin with.

Ys Seven is disappointing in another critical aspect, and that's the music. There are loads of different tracks in the game, but almost none of them are notable. Falcom has a heritage of making the best game music in history, and delivering a soundtrack that's merely adequate is not good enough. Like with the story and combat, there are a couple times the music does its job well, but 90% of the time, it's just kind of there, not being memorable in the least. If this was a different franchise, the music would be more than good enough. But if you make a game with a history, you have things you need to live up to.

Adding on to my pile of complaints, this is an ugly game. It’s all because it came out on PSP. Ys Seven looks better than an N64 game, but not by much. On the original PSP screen, I’m sure this looked adequate. But I played this on a 65” TV in 4K, and the technical compromises were too obvious. It's unfortunate, because all the other Ys games made in the 2000s with PC as the primary platform, like Ys 6, have a timeless quality to them. Their use of 3D and 2D scales beautifully to any screen size. The problem is, that it’s an aesthetic not even the PS2 was able to handle. When Ys 6 was ported to PS2, they had to make the game look worse for it to run properly. And when it came to making Ys Seven I’m sure they did their best with what they had to work with, but I kinda wish they’d made this a 2D game instead. The PSP was simply too crappy to do this game justice.

For Ys series fans, I’d still recommend Ys Seven. Just temper your expectations a bit. Even though this is the worst Ys game I've played since Ys 5, it's still better than your average RPG. Combat still requires you learn enemy patterns and time dodges, as you can't brute force your way to victory by grinding levels or items. And it's relatively free from tedium. Probably the absolute worst sequence in the game is how it opens, as it took me 40 minutes of running around town before the game let me explore the first field and fight monsters. After that, it stuck closely to the template established by Ys 6. Even if I'm disappointed with how this game turned out, there's still enough of what I want from Ys in here that I went away reasonably happy. I just wanted a more potent and powerful Ys experience. Guess I'll have to put my hopes in the next game, whenever it comes out on PC.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100769008', 'num_games_owned': 643, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 2673, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2669, 'last_played': 1665250647}
review:
[h1]Счастливое число Адола[/h1]

С данной игрой я познакомился в 2010 году на PSP, где и прошёл её впервые. Узнав о том, что Ys Seven добралась до ПК с улучшенной графикой и 60 FPS, я приобрёл не задумываясь. На текущий момент, игра пройдена на Hard и Nightmare, все шероховатости какие я заметил с PC-портом, исправлены и настало время поведать об игре.

Сюжет игры стартует примерно через полгода после событий Ys VI: The Ark of Napishtim. Война Альтаго с Романской Империей подошла к концу и обе стороны зализывают раны. Адол и Доги пребывают в столицу Альтаго в поисках приключений и вскоре получают задание - выяснить причины появления неизлечимой болезни именуемой "Исканская Лихорадка" от  которой страдает страна. Король подозревает, что болезнь как-то связана с драконами-хранителями Альтаго и просит Адола исследовать местное святилище... С этого момента и начинается приключение огненно-рыжего мечника. Должен сказать, что сюжет в игре хорошо проработан, а концовка и вовсе способна пробить на слезу.
[list]
[*]Геймплей

Ys Seven является переломной частью в серии, так как с её выходом, сериал сменил курс с  одиночной ARPG на партийную ARPG. Вроде ничего серьёзного, но на геймплей это повлияло кардинально. В партии одновременно могут присутствовать до трёх бойцов между которыми игрок свободно переключается, типов атак тоже три, соответственно. Режущие - годятся против большинства врагов,  Пронзающие - против летающих монстров, Силовые - против бронированных. Оружие, как и многие другие вещи можно крафтить из добытых предметов. У каждого оружия в игре есть своя способность, изучив которую (просто используя) игрок сможет назначать приём на любое другое вооружение. Одновременно можно назначить до 4-ех скиллов на персонажа, которые так же поддаются прокачке, как и сам персонаж. Кроме здоровья у бойца так же имеются две шкалы: SP - местного заменителя маны для способностей и Extra - шкала тайной техники (читай - суперудар).

[*]Мир и квесты

Как и в предыдущих играх серии, он условно-открытый с кучей секретов и неочевидных тайников. Ближе к середине игры игроку дадут  телепорт между локациями. Квестов в игре всего 20 и все они типа "Убей-Принеси" с оговорками. То зверушек пастуху вернуть, то серьги, натаскать стройматериала для мельницы, убить босса и т.д. Кстати, боссы как всегда шикарны. С повышением уровня сложности у них появляются новые атаки и немного меняется поведение, что может дать жару неподготовленным к таким сюрпризам приключенцам.

[*]Звук и музыка

Диалоги соответствуют оригиналу с PSP т.е. не озвучены. Зато музыка просто потрясная. Композиции подобраны очень удачно, а при битвах с боссами градус эпичности зашкаливает. Композиторы жгут. 

[*]Техническая часть

Играю с релиза и имелись некоторые проблемы. В частности, проблема 30/60 FPS, когда боссы очень активно восстанавливают здоровье или часто атакуют суперударами (схожая проблема была с DS 2 на ПК, когда оружие ломалось в 2 раза быстрее). Её и другие мелкие баги уже пофиксили после чего к порту придираться уже не хочется. Графику подтянули, но это будет заметно лишь тем, кто застал оригинал на PSP, так как мутноватые текстуры всё ещё встречаются. Разумеется, об оптимизации говорить особо нечего - игра совершенно не жрёт ресурсы, как и должно быть.
[/list]
Вердикт. Если вы любитель ARPG и Ys в частности, то настоятельно рекомендую к покупке, если ещё не купили. Остальным игра так же подойдёт как отправная точка в сериале, так как связь семёрки с предыдущими играми не особо важна для понимания. Дерзайте!


P. S. YS VIII, когда же ты выйдешь наконец?!

review:
昔からあるゲームシリーズですね、懐かしく思い買ってしまいました。
システム、ストーリー、演出など、総じてセンスが古い。古き良き和製ARPGってとこでしょうか。そう古くない作のようだけど。
3Dの必要ないし、聖剣2とかクロノとかの時代でも作れるようなゲーム性です。ファルコムに若手はいないのか。
戦闘アクションはサクサク進みますが、ボス戦のみゴリ押しが効かない毎度の流れになります。半キャラずらしの頃はボスに勝てない→レベル上げ→装備を更新がセオリーでしたが、意識せずとも進行できます。

シリーズファンにはオススメです。(スペックに思い出補正推奨)
若い人には逆に新鮮かもね。昔は私もアドルより若かったんですよ。
まぁ、正直イースじゃなかったら親指が下向いてるでしょうね。


新作？文句垂れつつ買いますよ。

author: {'steamid': '76561197975181554', 'num_games_owned': 560, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2413, 'last_played': 1517668637}
review:
PSP以来2度目のプレイで、40時間ほどかけてクリアしました。
今までSteamで販売されるイースシリーズは日本語が無く歯痒い思いをしてきましたが、今回ようやく日本語テキストまで(音声は英語)対応ということで、久々に遊んでみました。
コントローラはXBOX ONEの物を使用しました。

元がPSPなのでグラフィックは仕方ないですが、それを補って余りある面白さがあると思います。
ストーリー、アクション、ボス戦など、ゲームとしての良さはしっかり作り込まれていて、プレイしててストレスを感じにくい作りになっているので、爽快なゲームプレイが楽しめました。

個人的に特に良かった点としては、シリーズ初の3人パーティー構成という試みです。旧作の3属性攻撃の単純な置換えではなく、キャラが倒れても他のキャラにチェンジしてすぐにゲームオーバーにならないので、ゲームプレイのテンポを落とさないという面があり、アクションゲームとして優れた設計だと思います。ただ、旧作ファン向けに、アドル一人モードプレイなんてもの実装されていると良かったです。(続編のYs 8にはありますね)

ところで、今回より導入されたフラッシュガードですが、本編で全く解説が出てこないので気付かない人は最後まで気付かないのではないかと思います。これが使えるかどうかでゲーム性が大きく変わるので、もう少し説明があっても良かったのではないかと思いました。(高難易度プレイの場合は、知らないとクリア不可能かと思いますが…)

イースシリーズというか、ファルコム作品の特徴として音楽の良さが上げられますが、今回もフィールドやボスを初めとして実に印象深い曲が多かったように思います。個人的にはシリーズ中で一番好きかもしれません。

システム面ですが、セーブ/ロード等の各種データアクセスが非常に早く、待たされることが一切無いという点が挙げられます。おかげで、ゲームをすぐに始められて、すぐに終えられるので、空いた時間に手軽にプレイできてとても良かったです。
ただその反面かもしれませんが、テロップ表示や技の発動のタイミングでゲームの動きが一瞬止まる場合があります。そのタイミングでデータが読み込まれてる感じなので、移植の作り込みの問題かと思います。これは改善してほしいところです。

以上、再プレイしての簡単な感想です。
グラフィックが物足りないのは仕方ないですが、ゲームとしての面白さは十分に備えていると思いますので、是非ともお勧めしたい作品です。

余談ですが、PC-98からシリーズ一通り遊んできた者としては、(パブリッシャが異なるとはいえ)PCにイースが戻ってきてくれることが嬉しかったです。セルセタもよろしくお願いします。

author: {'steamid': '76561198160222473', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 1817, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1745, 'last_played': 1523890538}
review:
YsⅧがもう間もなくリリースされるとのことなので、
前作である本作のレビューもとい雑感を書いておきます。
（Normalモードクリアしたので、更新します。）

ジャンルはアクションロールプレイングゲーム（ARPG)
最大３人からなるパーティーで、有効属性ごとにキャラをワンタッチで
切り替えて、敵を攻撃しながらエリアを開拓、探索してしていく
自由度が高めのゲームとなっています。

値段以上の価値はあると思います。
以下、部分的に見た感想と評価↓

【戦闘システム、移動性能】
アクション要素を含んでいるので、私個人として重要視するのはこの部分。
まずはそうですね・・・移動性能がぶっ飛んでいます。
リアリティを度外視した移動性能が、ストーリー開始直後から楽しめます。
イメージとしては、スキップしたら１０歩くらい進んでた・・
みたいな感じで、これをクールタイム無しで連打出来ます。
その為RPGや探索系にありがちな「移動時間で無駄な時間を浪費する」
というプレイヤー側の負荷が大幅に減らされています。もう本当に感動しました。

次いで攻撃性能ですが、キャラごとに癖があります。
もちろんいい意味で。
使ってみて分かるキャラごとの良さというのがこれまた絶妙で・・
パワー系は重い一撃を想定したキャラメイクとなっており、爽快な一撃を理想の形で放てますし、
遠距離のタイプは速射型の制圧タイプと、範囲型のマジシャンタイプと分かれていて、
ちゃんとニーズに応えてくれているなと感じました。
そして剣を主軸としたバランスタイプは万能というイメージ。
主人公がこのタイプなので、操作に慣れるまではこのキャラで慣らしていく感じになるんじゃないかなと思いました。
（もちろん全体通して安定してるので後半も大活躍です）

最初に書いたとおり、戦闘の属性は３すくみとなっているので
ストーリーやステージを通して、ほぼ全てのキャラを一通り触ることになります。
その中で自分に合ったキャラを見つけて育てていくといいかなと思います！


【ストーリーやダンジョン攻略】
ストーリーはネタバレになるのであまり詳しくは書けないですが、
「王道」に沿った分かりやすいストーリーであると言えます。
それをベースとして、意外性、メッセージ性も兼ねており
いいバランスで仕上がっているなという印象を受けました。

ダンジョン攻略についてですが、さまざまなギミックを取り入れた
ダンジョンを楽しめるので、飽き等は来ないんじゃないかなと思います。

※追記
ストーリーとして、本当によくまとまっていました。
ゲームで泣いたのは久しぶりです、凄く良い終わり方でした。

そしてラストで全キャラを駆使したオールスターなボス戦がはじまりますので
どのキャラも満遍なく育てておかないと苦労します。


【マイナス要素】
やはりゲームパッドの初期設定ですね。
必殺技（スキル）を設定する部分でXYABとある中のXの部分が、
ダンジョン探索や攻略に用いるアイテムウィンドウを開くボタンと併合しているため、
最初の設定のままだと必殺技を出したいのにアイテムウィンドウが開いてしまうという
ストレスしか生み出さない仕様になっています。
プレイ前に是非、アイテムウィンドウの部分を設定で併合しない箇所に変えることをおすすめします。

後は日本語音声が実装されてなかったところですね。
ゲーム機からの移植ということで、原作では日本語音声が入っていたということなので、
単に未プレイの私は「聞いてみたかったな・・」と思いました。
その為、英語音声はOFFにしてテキストのみで楽しんでいます。
（声はイメージで補いました）

【総評】
アクション性は申し分なくて、ストーリーも綺麗に進んでいく
素晴らしい出来のゲーム。買って損はないと言えるでしょう

review:
I cannot think of a game that would be better served by removing all of its story and cutscenes. I could write paragraphs over every line of dialogue that made me cringe or made me think "that's dumb", but the biggest indictment comes at the very end of the game (heavy spoilers):

[spoiler]It's revealed that all of the earthquakes, monster attacks, and Iskan fever occur because Altago has lost its "balance" (whatever that means), and the Root of All Existence has to reset the world (ie kill everything and then have it reborn). This process occurs every 200 years or so. At the end of the game you kill the Root of All Existence and... everything goes back to normal. The balance is restored anyway, the entire ritual was unnecessary. Don't tell me that's not a contradiction.[/spoiler]

Gameplay-wise, the newer additions only serve to annoy. In previous Ys games, you would buy equipment and find them in chests. In this game, you still do this, but getting end-game gear and medicine requires synthesis, which is like buying except you need to farm the ingredients. This is just adding a step. It doesn't make it more fun; it just takes longer. 

Fighting monsters is fun, jumping around spamming skills and dodging monster attacks is still like it is in every Ys game. But does the game NEED to STOP and SHOW me a new area, having the camera pan over the land and monsters I'm about to fight? Just let me DO these things, stop wasting my TIME. And while I'm on the subject, having to stand still to heal is [b]still not a good idea, this shouldn't be a thing[/b].

This is the weakest entry in the Ys series. Either Ys I, Origin, or Felghana are the best. It's still a Ys game, so if you just want more Ys then it's fine, I guess, but I can only hope this isn't a sign of things to come for Ys 8.

Two out of five Lennys

author: {'steamid': '76561198026452979', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 4757, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3515, 'last_played': 1594172234}
review:
Ys Seven est un Action RPG très dynamique et nerveux à la difficulté justement dosée, dans lequel l'action est omniprésente, et rythmée par des musiques énergiques.
Votre équipe se compose de trois personnages, chacun spécialisé dans le maniement d'une arme dont les propriétés influent sur leur efficacité sur les monstres que vous rencontrerez. Vous pouvez changer la composition de votre équipe avec les personnages disponibles à tout moment.

Ici, peu, voire pas de place à la magie, vous pouvez frapper avec votre arme et apprendre des techniques appelées "skills", que vous pouvez faire évoluer et qui dépendent de l'arme que votre personnage tient. Une barre de skill se remplit quand vous attaquez et se vide lorsque vous utiliser vos techniques spéciales. 
Les esquives sont vives et souvent très utiles, vous permettant de vous dégager rapidement quand une situation devient défavorable, ou pour éviter les coups portés à vos personnages.

Cet aspect du gameplay en fait un jeu relativement bourrin mais très facile à prendre en main, où l'action est prenante et où les séquences de combat sont mouvementées et sans temps morts.

Le jeu possède de nombreuses quêtes annexes et une quantité importante d'objets à collecter, et la possibilité de créer de nouveaux équipements avec la "synthèse", qui vous forcera à rassembler des matériaux plus ou moins rares pour avoir accès à des objets ou armes exclusives, allongeant ainsi la durée de vie qui est tout à fait acceptable (comptez entre 30 et 35 heures hors quêtes annexes). Et pour les courageux, la possibilité de faire le jeu en mode "Nightmare" qui propose un challenge à la hauteur des plus ambitieux.
